qas.question: What Russian-Austrian agreement preceded the Seven Years War that started in 1755-56?

answers.text: June 2, 1746, Austria and Russia concluded a defensive alliance that covered their own territory and Poland against attack by Prussia or the Ottoman Empire

qas.question: According to the Russian-Austrian pact of 1746, what would happen to Silesia in the event of hostilities with Prussia?

answers.text: They also agreed to a secret clause that promised the restoration of Silesia and the countship of Glatz (now Kłodzko, Poland) to Austria

qas.question: What other area was mentioned regarding Prussian dominion in the Russian-Austrian pact?

answers.text: the countship of Glatz (now Kłodzko, Poland) to Austria

qas.question: What individual was the main target of the pact?

answers.text: Their real desire, however, was to destroy Frederick’s power altogether

qas.question: Why couldn't Petrovich persuade Austria to invade Prussia?

answers.text: he could not persuade Austrian statesman Wenzel Anton von Kaunitz to commit to offensive designs against Prussia

context: In 1756 Austria was making military preparations for war with Prussia and pursuing an alliance with Russia for this purpose. On <a0_0>June 2, 1746, Austria and Russia concluded a defensive alliance that covered their own territory and Poland against attack by Prussia or the Ottoman Empire<a0_0/>. <a1_0>They also agreed to a secret clause that promised the restoration of Silesia and <a2_0>the countship of Glatz (now Kłodzko, Poland) to Austria<a2_0/><a1_0/> in the event of hostilities with Prussia. <a3_0>Their real desire, however, was to destroy Frederick’s power altogether<a3_0/>, reducing his sway to his electorate of Brandenburg and giving East Prussia to Poland, an exchange that would be accompanied by the cession of the Polish Duchy of Courland to Russia. Aleksey Petrovich, Graf (count) Bestuzhev-Ryumin, grand chancellor of Russia under Empress Elizabeth, was hostile to both France and Prussia, but <a4_0>he could not persuade Austrian statesman Wenzel Anton von Kaunitz to commit to offensive designs against Prussia<a4_0/> so long as Prussia was able to rely on French support.
